byline.contributor: Nick Cumming-Bruce reported from Geneva, and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations. Anne Barnard contributed reporting from Beirut, Lebanon, and Rick Gladstone from New York.
byline.original: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and SOMINI SENGUPTA

abstract: Russian planes, under an international emergency aid agreement, will begin airdrops to provide food and medicine to war-ravaged towns across Syria; program, partly financed by United States and launched by United Nations World Food program, will specifically target city of Deir al-Zour, which is surrounded by Islamic State forces and difficult to access by land.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations World Food Program will start its first airdrops in Syria in coming days, using aircraft provided by a Russian contractor.

headline.main: Agreement Clears the Way for Airdrops of Humanitarian Aid in Syria
headline.print_headline: Agreement Clears the Way for Airdrops of Humanitarian Aid in Syria

snippet: The United Nations World Food Program will start its first airdrops in Syria in coming days, using aircraft provided by a Russian contractor.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
